results.title: Setting out
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Surveys the chief events in Australian and world history that have influenced our migration patterns and immigration laws. Notes Aboriginal migration to Australia, the First Fleet, the discovery of gold, the land boom, drought and depression in the 1890s, Federation, World War I and after, the 1930s depression, post-war immigration, multiculturalism and Asian immigration. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Setting and fixing joinery
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
Shows method of setting and fixing joinery including bedding a stone sill; use of weather bar; temporary fixing of window frame frame; broken bond to accommodate frame when not brick size; fixing frames by metal tie, breeze brick and wood slip.

results.title: Sets: construction and display
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Lawler and Centre for Educational Television Overseas
results.brief_description: Studies television studio set design, concentrating on three common production situations: - the presenter set’, theinterview set’, and the `drama set’. Includes details of their design, planning and construction. Emphasises the need for co-ordination with studio engineers. Well presented and easy to understand with good use of models as an instructive tool.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lawrie Lawler and Centre for Educational Television Overseas

results.title: Sets and numbers
results.brief_description: Uses animation to define the mathematical concept of sets and numbers. Introduces the concepts of order, cardinal number, empty set and equivalent set. Explains that consecutive numbers are just one larger than the preceding numeral.

results.title: Set no limits: Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games
results.brief_description: Australian Paralympians don’t often receive as much publicity as their non paralympic counterparts. This video attempts to even out the balance by providing highlights and victories from previous Paralympic Games, which began in 1960. Highlighted on the video is Lizzie (as in lizard), mascot of the Paralympic Games who symbolises the dreams and motivation of the competitors. This section is narrated by Olivia Newton-John. Suitable for primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Set design in Sweet Country
results.brief_description: Australian western set on the Northern Territory frontier in the 1920s, where justice itself is put on trial when an aged Aboriginal farmhand shoots a white man in self-defense and goes on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Outlaws and the end
constellations_primary.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.description:
In Kaytej director Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country, Aboriginal stockman Sam (Hamilton Morris) goes on the run after shooting white station owner Harry March (Ewen Leslie) in self-defense.

Exploring racism, trauma and morality through a western genre lens, Sweet Country is based on the story of Willaberta Jack, the great uncle of Alyawarra sound recordist and co-producer David Tranter, who translated the tale into storyboards, some of which are reproduced here.

The action unfolds 30km from Alice Springs in the fictional town of Henry, which was created by extending and adding to structures built for a previous film. Its dusty streets and sun-bleached buildings embody western motifs, which are also apparent in the narrative, props and costumes.

The costumes were hand-painted with dust and powder to blend into the harsh landscape – except for Harry’s black-and-red outfit, which Thornton wanted to look like “a poisonous redback spider”.

“Sweet Country is a western. A period western set in Central Australia. It has all the elements of the genre - the frontier, confiscation of land, subordination and conquest of a people and epic sweeping landscapes.” – Warwick Thornton, director of Sweet Country
description_for_label:
In Kaytej director Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country, Aboriginal stockman Sam (Hamilton Morris) goes on the run after shooting white station owner Harry March (Ewen Leslie) in self-defense.

Exploring racism, trauma and morality through a western genre lens, Sweet Country is based on the story of Willaberta Jack, the great uncle of Alyawarra sound recordist and co-producer David Tranter, who translated the tale into storyboards, some of which are reproduced here.

The action unfolds 30km from Alice Springs in the fictional town of Henry, which was created by extending and adding to structures built for a previous film. Its dusty streets and sun-bleached buildings embody western motifs, which are also apparent in the narrative, props and costumes.

The costumes were hand-painted with dust and powder to blend into the harsh landscape – except for Harry’s black-and-red outfit, which Thornton wanted to look like “a poisonous redback spider”.

“Sweet Country is a western. A period western set in Central Australia. It has all the elements of the genre - the frontier, confiscation of land, subordination and conquest of a people and epic sweeping landscapes.” – Warwick Thornton, director of Sweet Country

results.title: Set design in Little J and Big Cuz
results.creator_credit: Tony Thorne and Ned Lander Media Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Five-year-old Little J and nine-year-old Big Cuz are a couple of indigenous Australian kids living with their Nanna and old dog. All their friends are nearby, and school is just a stroll away along a bush track.

constellations_primary.name: Drawing on influences
constellations_primary.description: Waves of animators have been inspired by the style of previous animators to help tell their own stories.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Thorne and Ned Lander Media Pty Ltd
results.description:
There’s a world of adventure over Little J and Big Cuz’s back fence. Their house is magically located at the doorstep of the desert, bush and coast – environments that represent where the show’s writers are from. And as locations in the first animated show made for Indigenous Australian kids by an Indigenous crew, these environments aren’t just settings for great stories – they reflect the different landscapes of the people the show was made for. To the show’s fans, Little J and Big Cuz live in the same place they do.

They also speak like them. Each season, Indigenous communities could choose an episode to have translated into their traditional language. Naturally, they typically picked episodes set in locations that represent their country.
description_for_label:
There’s a world of adventure over Little J and Big Cuz’s back fence. Their house is magically located at the doorstep of the desert, bush and coast – environments that represent where the show’s writers are from. And as locations in the first animated show made for Indigenous Australian kids by an Indigenous crew, these environments aren’t just settings for great stories – they reflect the different landscapes of the people the show was made for. To the show’s fans, Little J and Big Cuz live in the same place they do.

They also speak like them. Each season, Indigenous communities could choose an episode to have translated into their traditional language. Naturally, they typically picked episodes set in locations that represent their country.

results.title: Set design in Dishonored 2
results.brief_description: Dishonored 2 is set 15 years after the Lord Regent has been vanquished and the dreaded Rat Plague has passed into history. An otherworldly usurper has seized the throne from Empress Emily Kaldwin, leaving the fate of the Isles hanging in the balance.

constellations_primary.name: Robots, robots everywhere
constellations_primary.description: Steampunk aesthetics, malevolent AI and cybernetic cops push the frontiers of imagination in this Constellation inspired by Dishonored 2.

results.description:
The jungle bordering Karnaca is reclaiming the city. Weeds sprout from concrete and trees grow through buildings sprawled with ominous graffiti, a sign of the unrest simmering beneath the sun-soaked surface. The setting of Dishonored 2 is a lived environment.   

Creators Arkane Studios combined 500 years of fictional history with real-world inspirations like Barcelona, Los Angeles and Havana when they were designing Karnaca. Visual artists were hired to conceptualise, texture and colour the world, which helped define the bustling city and its distinct characters and locations. Players sneak through its alleyways, traverse its rooftops and strike from its shadows as Emily Kaldwin or Corvo Attano – assassins trying to topple a pretender to the city’s throne.
description_for_label:

results.title: Sestrieres 1949
results.creator_credit: Hugh Wyn Griffith and Oxford University Film Society
results.brief_description: This film is a photographic impression of a skiing holiday taken by 300 British students. No text and musical accompaniament acts as a narrative to the images we see. Great footage of skiers and Italian Alps. Music by Christofer Shaw and photography by Michael Warne, Charles Carson.
